The Tower of Hanoi

Originally written: July 19, 2020

The Tower of Hanoi is a mathÂ­eÂ­matÂ­iÂ­cal puzÂ­zle, ofÂ­ten inÂ­troÂ­duced to unÂ­derÂ­gradÂ­uÂ­ate colÂ­lege stuÂ­dents. At face value, the puzÂ­zle seems pointÂ­less. After careÂ­ful inÂ­specÂ­tion, it turns out we can conÂ­jure up a conÂ­cise reÂ­curÂ­sive alÂ­goÂ­rithm. If your not faÂ­milÂ­iar with reÂ­curÂ­sion, conÂ­sider checkÂ­ing out my preÂ­viÂ­ous post. In a nutÂ­shell, reÂ­curÂ­sion is useÂ­ful when a probÂ­lem can be broÂ­ken down into smaller probÂ­lems of the same form as the origÂ­iÂ­nal. With some imagÂ­iÂ­naÂ­tion, the Tower of Hanoi meets this reÂ­quireÂ­ment.

Why?

And you may be wonÂ­derÂ­ing why you should care. After all, there is an itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tive soÂ­luÂ­tion to the puzÂ­zleâ€”just do a Google search. Well, this toy probÂ­lem shows that reÂ­curÂ­sion can inÂ­spire simÂ­pler code than itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion. Although I'm not goÂ­ing to cover the itÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tive soÂ­luÂ­tion exÂ­plicÂ­itly here, you should look it up. By comÂ­parÂ­ing the two soÂ­luÂ­tions, it's clear that the reÂ­curÂ­sive one feaÂ­tures less code and easÂ­ier to read.

Given the paraÂ­graph above, I am goÂ­ing to emÂ­phaÂ­size that reÂ­curÂ­sion isn't a suÂ­perÂ­ï¬‚uÂ­ous, comÂ­pliÂ­cated techÂ­nique. It has leÂ­gitÂ­iÂ­mate uses in the real world. If it will make your code easÂ­ier to write and unÂ­derÂ­stand, conÂ­sider usÂ­ing it. Now, it's not alÂ­ways betÂ­ter. The Rules

For those unÂ­faÂ­milÂ­iar with the puzÂ­zle, I'll quickly exÂ­plain the rules. There is a board with three poles and an arrangeÂ­ment of disks. The disks are each of a difÂ­ferÂ­ent size, and iniÂ­tially, they are arranged in a cone shape on a sinÂ­gle pole. The goal is to move all the disksâ€“one at a timeâ€“to anÂ­other a pole, once again formÂ­ing the cone shape. Also, a larger disk canÂ­not be stacked on top of a smaller disk at any time.

Recursive Solution

Once again, the Tower of Hanoi can be solved reÂ­curÂ­sively. It works beÂ­cause we can split the game into subÂ­puzÂ­zles. These subÂ­puzÂ­zles are themÂ­selves a miniverÂ­sion of The Tower of Hanoiâ€“which can then be solved in the same fashÂ­ion as the bigÂ­ger verÂ­sion. To note, the alÂ­goÂ­rithm will alÂ­ways proÂ­duce a valid set of game-winÂ­ning moves. So you can win the game every time.

Before jumpÂ­ing into the code, let's imagÂ­ine what the soÂ­luÂ­tion's strucÂ­ture could look like. To start, we'll laÂ­bel the three poles A, B, and C. Then, let's say there's a stack of h disks on pole A. This arrangeÂ­ment is the iniÂ­tial setupâ€“no surÂ­prises here. As a reÂ­minder, to win, the player needs to move all the disks to anÂ­other pole.

Yet, to move pole A's largest disk, h-1 disks need to be shufÂ­ï¬‚ed to an auxÂ­ilÂ­iary poleâ€“let's say pole B. Of course, this is just solvÂ­ing a slightly smaller verÂ­sion of the same puzÂ­zle. So, we need to move h-2 disks someÂ­whereâ€¦ You should see where this is goÂ­ing.

What hapÂ­pens when we have reÂ­duced our way to subÂ­puzÂ­zle conÂ­sistÂ­ing of one disk? This sitÂ­uÂ­aÂ­tion is the easÂ­iÂ­est to hanÂ­dleâ€“just move diÂ­rectly move the disk to the tarÂ­get poleâ€“in this case pole C.

Now, in genÂ­eral, once the largest disk of a subÂ­puzÂ­zle has moved been moved the tarÂ­get pole, we can then move all the disks placed on the auxÂ­ilÂ­iary pole over to the tarÂ­get pole as well. To do this, we are again just solvÂ­ing a smaller verÂ­sion of the puzÂ­zleâ€“we are just changÂ­ing which poles are laÂ­beled as the auxÂ­ilÂ­iary and the tarÂ­get.

In sumÂ­mary, we are reÂ­peatÂ­edly movÂ­ing the large disk of a subÂ­puzÂ­zle afÂ­ter the smaller disks above have been moved to the auxÂ­ilÂ­iary pole. The key is to corÂ­rectly track which poles should be the tarÂ­get and the auxÂ­ilÂ­iary as the alÂ­goÂ­rithm twists through the self calls. Assuming we do this corÂ­rectly, the puzÂ­zle will be solved by solvÂ­ing all the subÂ­puzÂ­zles in turn.

Some Code
